course.subject: MECH
course.name: Automotive Engineering
course.description: This course teaches fundamental technologies in automotive engineering. It is targeted at the general student body and opens to all the students of science, engineering, or business majors. It will cover all the important aspects of automobile engineering and technologies, including its history, development, and current state. Content wise, it will cover key components of an automobile, i.e., the engine, transmission (both manual and automatic), brake system, control, chassis, etc. In addition, it will cover the managerial and operational aspects of modern automobile companies.

reviews.author: Fredrika
reviews.title: Shit course
reviews.comment_content: Content is ok  ,if you are really interested in car .
reviews.comment_teaching: Just refer to the notes ,and the TA are nice.the group project is easy .
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the content is good, the exam , mid term is very  hard.if you are not have great interested in the mech course .Don't choose it.
Especially for year 1 student. Those joins this course most of them are year 2,or 3 mech  students.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is ok .Just have a group project. The group project weight is about 40%of the project mark.
No homework are needed

reviews.author: Captain UST
reviews.title: Pointless Lecture + Must attend Lab
reviews.comment_content:
Overview of the automotive engineering industry, including its history, development and current state.
Learn and understand the major and important aspects of your own car, i.e., the engine, transmission, drive-axle system, suspension system, brake system, control, etc., their inter-relations.
Fundamental scientific and engineering knowledge, methods,  and principles underneath an automotive, e.g.: the working principle of a transmission, the gear system as a fundamental mechanical system, etc.
Part 1: Introduction
Part 2: Preliminaries
Part 3: Engines
Part 4: Manual transmission
Part 5: Automatic transmission
Part 6: Axles and drives
Part 7: Brakes
Part 8: Suspension
Part 9: Steering
reviews.comment_teaching:
Well right from the start I don't enjoy the lesson ,not because its nature is a 9am lesson, but the professor is just reading from the ppt. I think that attending his lesson is a waste of time so I study this course after midterm.

In the lab, there is a TA from HK, just ask him stuffs and he will help you
reviews.comment_grading:
I think that the grade is good as many things are shown from the ppt in the lessons.
However please do note that some questions in Final have not appeared in the lecture notes or his optional exercises. SO you are a sitting duck while in the exam.

Midterm mean : 81/100 (I might have forgotten the full mark) I am slightly above the mean.
Final : there is no such statistics available and I do not know how many marks that I have scored
I scored a B.

Grading:>Computer Lab       10-15%
>Mid-term exam     35-40%
Closed book (but you are allowed to bring 3 “cheat” sheets, or six pages counting the front and back sides)
Mostly multiple choices format
Covers only Part 2 and 3
>Final exam     50%
Closed book (but you are allowed to bring 3 “cheat” sheets, or six pages counting the front and back sides)
Mostly multiple choices format
Covers any parts after Part 3
reviews.comment_workload: Light indeed.You can skip the lecture as I have mentioned that the Professor is just reading the powerpoint. There is no homework or quiz on the lesson or off the lesson. You just have to prepare a cheat sheet for the midterm and Final.In addition You must attend the lab

reviews.author: andyleunghk
reviews.title: Shit course
reviews.comment_content: Content is ok  ,if you are really interested in car .
reviews.comment_teaching: Just refer to the notes ,and the TA are nice.the group project is easy .
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the content is good, the exam , mid term is very  hard.if you are not have great interested in the mech course .Don't choose it.
Especially for year 1 student. Those joins this course most of them are year 2,or 3 mech  students.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is ok .Just have a group project. The group project weight is about 40%of the project mark.
No homework are needed

reviews.author: Hugo Chin
reviews.comment_content:
Quiet interesting.
Studying components on cars.
If you are interested about cars or even mechanical engineering, this course provides you very fundamental but not difficult contents to study.

Before mid-term, you will study:
-Some preliminary knowledge (Just some force and motion)
-Engine
After mid-term you will study:
-Manual and Automatic Transmission
-Axles and Drive
-Brakes
-Suspensions
-Steering

Luckily is that the stuff in mid-term will not appear in the final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Tang's teaching is quiet good I think.
However, he should follow his schedule stated in canvas.
As he just got 2h every week and he got 9 topics to teach.
Mid-term has already occupied one week.
So imagine how "chur" he has to be in order to teach everything and he barely finished teaching all his content before the final.

Also, he has to upload his ppt earlier.
He got many times that he is teaching his ppt but those were not uploaded to canvas so we can just listen without our notes. Reach some body who has source of this course if he keeps on being like this.

Moreover, the lab sessions are quiet straight.
There is more than 50 students doing the lab in each sessions, but we just got 2 TAs.
And for most of the time we will finish the lab materials in about the same time. So while one TA is going to solve some problems raised by other students, another TA has to check the work of more than 50 students.
Imagine how long you have to raise your hand to ask the TA to come to check your work.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know if it is good or not.
I got around mean+0.5sd in mid-term.
And other grades were not uploaded to the canvas or even letting us know about our score.

BTW you can bring cheat-sheet in mid-term and final.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 lab per week.
And final project is the largest workload in this course I think.
You have to mate those materials provided and work them properly and present it to the TAs.
Presentation is quiet "hea" so it is not a great deal and don't need to worry about it.
If you want to get a better grade, you have to find out more sources from the web, like designing a manual transmission system and a suspension system, that will make up around 30 % or the project.
But project occupy a small proportion in the final grade.
So decide by yourself to do those extras or not.

reviews.author: UGH
reviews.title: Best course materials
reviews.comment_content: Everything you would want to study about automobile mechanisms.
reviews.comment_teaching:
When I was studying it was a blended learning mode. Professor recorded the introduction of the materials and its a discussion session in lectures. Students will be expected to have listened to his video and have learnt the basic before you go in.
TA again from mainland so holding a strong accent but still pretty helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Group project Solidworks assembly of a car, the grading of the project is pretty chill though, at the end the TA will let you adjust and get the grade.
Midterm and Final are easy if you studied well enough.
reviews.comment_workload: Best average of all i will say, it will depends on your level of understanding of cars before you started the course but it won't be hard to pick up. I will say this is the best 1000 level course certainly in MAE.

reviews.author: Kellycat
reviews.title: 我對車完全無認識先俾workload B, 有認識可以好輕鬆
reviews.comment_content:
It made use of blended learning (canvas you read the notes before lesson (supposedly) with discussions in class). Some of the question in the discussion in class will appear in midterm/ final)
All about a car, like brake, transmission, suspension, rotating, u-joints, differentials. I am a normal girl with no knowledge about it but I can catch up by studying most of the notes and discussion notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is quite keen on teaching, but the TAs (li Chen, qianhang Yan) could be better in the ways of slowing down a bit in lab sessions.
reviews.comment_grading: I got less than 1 sd above mean with unknown marks and statistics in final, attend lab (finish the task, easy, and 叫做sign attendance) and finish the lab final (build a car using the given components in solidworks) on time and fulfil the requirement, I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light
no homework, online quiz for self revision but no contributing to your final grades. If you are confident, you can skip them, but some of the questions may appear in quiz and even midterm/ final.

reviews.author: Maurice
reviews.comment_content:
(According to the lecture notes provided by prof)

• Overview of the automotive engineering industry, including
its history, development and current state.
• Understand the major and important aspects of your own car,
i.e., the engine, transmission, drive-axle system, suspension
system, brake system, control, etc.
• Managerial and operational aspects of modern automobile
companies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lab is fun. You are required to use software to assemble a car at the end of this course
reviews.comment_grading:
Computer Lab 25%
Midterm (cheat sheet permitted, All MCs) 25%
Final (cheat sheet permitted, All MCs) 40%
Quiz (All MCs) 10%

Grade is quite good with a mean of B.
reviews.comment_workload: You are required to study lecture noted at home before each lecture. Professor will not explain the notes in lecture but only to explain questions.

reviews.author: Gman
reviews.comment_content: This course explains all mechanisms in a functioning car such as steering, engines, transmissions and so on.
reviews.comment_teaching:
They adopted blended learning for this course this semester and I hope they change it back to normal.

Each week, they would upload the teaching materials for the coming lessons on CANVAS, where we had to go through the slides ourselves and prepare the answers based on another set of slides related to that topic.

Lectures can very become monotonous and boring at times.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Quizzes
10%

Computer Lab
25%  (including attendance, assignments and the final-week project)

Mid-term Exam
25%

Final Exam
40%
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload for this course is rather light, which is good.
There are lab sessions once a week.
There are quizzes but they tell you in advance.
The final project is a group project of up to 3 students.

There are quite a lot of topics to go through for the whole semester so it's better to go through each week and recap them once in a while.

reviews.author: Ghoshjega
reviews.title: Very Interesting. But teaching isn't good.
reviews.comment_content: Content is appropriate. Engines, transmission, suspension covered in detail for a 1000 level course. But interest in cars is very much needed to excel in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is not good as it is blended learning from 2015. But this may change as the professor said it might change back to normal if many students don't prefer this style.

Good TAs.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is okay. 10to12 students get over 90. Mean is around 75. Lecture notes are available online to study.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Lab every week. In class graded quiz is said in advance. Final project is a group project with 3 students.

reviews.author: potat0
reviews.comment_content:
All the basics of how a car works ( parts of a car, transmission, steering, suspension, gears, differential, braking, etc.) + intro course to Solidworks.
The content itself is very interesting and probably the most interesting in terms of introductory mech courses.
Learning Solidworks is very very useful, whether you choose mech as a major or not, and it mkaes the course quite fun (unless the program keeps crashing... ) and since computer barns now have the software installed, completing the project is easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sigh... Another bad professor in mech. Very boring, horrible English and horrible ppt slides. The information is clearly copy pasted, and some of it is even wrong. Since it's the only material provided in the course, it's a bit sad. Don't really bother asking a question, you would be better off looking up the answer online rather than asking him and get both him and you confused...
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, fairly easy to get a good mark
100-95: A+
95-90: A
85-90: A-
I forgot the rest.
Open Computer cumulative exams (without internet, but nobody got caught when I took it).
The exams were fairly easy, only tricky question was about gears.
Labs are ok, easy to follow through but TAs are quite useless. You need to practice solidworks on your own to reach a suitable level to complete the final project.
Final project is by pairs and you need to finish a given model of a struck by adding suspensions, brakes and other components (which you will have already built in the labs), short report goes with it.
reviews.comment_workload: Nothing to do outside of class and final project can be done in about a day or two  for a complete Solidworks noob.

reviews.author: Vladimir Putin
reviews.title: Don't get fooled by a beautiful name of a course - IT'S A TRAP
reviews.comment_content: The content basically goes though the whole mechanism of car functioning including steering, strokes of internal combustion engine, differentials and so on - literally everything you have in a vehicle would be explained. However, the way it was explained deserves F grade... The course also includes labs where you have to build some parts of the car like an engine or a steering system using a computer software (SolidWorks if I'm not mistaken). The labs were as bad as lectures, there were like 40 students in each and just 2 TAs (sometimes just one), and you have to raise your hand for like 10 minutes before TA can come and help you, unless you are a pretty girl of course  (and yeah, you have to raise that hand for like 1000 times cause the software you gotta be using is quite laggy and difficult to work on - business student writing). Gotta admit though that the content itself was very interesting, but I would advise you rather to get to know all these things through wikipedia or youtube than signing up for this course...
reviews.comment_teaching:
Horrible, prof speaks poor english, makes a lot of grammatical mistakes in an exam and his lecture slides and videos. Furthermore, seems like this dude never drove a car himself and was teaching based on info he got from scrolling 9gag or 8fact. At one point he was claiming that the more miles per gallon a car can drive the less efficient it is. TAs were SLIGHTLY better than the prof.

Sometimes, prof would leave the class 20 minutes before the end with out asking if we had any questions or needed any help and let his TAs show us some "cool" stuff...

Summing up: the worst teaching I have experienced at HKUST
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm - mean;
Couple of in-class quizzes - no idea how I did on those;
Final - no idea as well
Got C in the end.
Moreover, those "brilliant" TAs underestimated my mid-term exam by 10% so I got these 10% back on paper checking session which probably saved me from D...
Might be missing something cause I took the course almost a year ago.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is moderately OK, prof explains all the material though his videos which you have to watch as a homework and on lectures you just discuss some extra stuff related to the videos, so lectures aren't really compulsory as long as they don't have a quizz. No attendance as well.

LAST WARNING: DON'T let him fool you by having an interesting name of the course as he did with me, he would DESTROY your whole interest in automobiles and the way they work.

reviews.author: Ric
reviews.title: A Course Pandering to Those Interested in Cars ONLY
reviews.comment_content:
This unparalleled CC course covers most mechanical systems of an automobile, and
will probably be a chance for getting a good grade, if not an eye-opener.
To be honest, I'm genuinely interested in Automotive Engineering, this course is one of the many reasons motivating me to opt for UST.
The teaching topics are arranged in terms of the major car systems:
Week 1 Introduction
Week 2 Preliminary Knowledge*
Week 3 Internal Combustion Engine (3.1~3.3)
Week 4 Internal Combustion Engine (3.4~3.7)
Week 5 Midterm exam
Week 6 Manual Transmissions
Week 7 Automatic Transmissions (5.1~5.3)
Week 8 Automatic Transmissions (5.4~5.6)*
Week 9 Axles & Drives
Week 10 Brakes
Week 11 Suspensions
Week 12 Steering
Week 13 Final Review
reviews.comment_teaching:
3 classes/ week supposedly, they are supposedly in such sequence:
1) pre-recorded Lecture* Watching (video+handout in CANVAS)
2) Physical Lecture (known as 'in-class interaction')(once a week)
3) SolidWorks Lab (need to take your attendance)

The professor seems passionate.

The lab echoes what has been taught in the lecture of the week, of course, it has easy assignments.

The only things to complain are the proficiency of English of the TAs & the hurried demonstration.
During the lab sessions, one of the TAs particularly struggled, prompting many students to ask him questions in PTH instead.
*remarks:
1) Only watch the video if you ain't motivated go through the entire handout yourselves, as he basically reads the handout.
2) During the demonstrations in LAB, NEVER TRY TO FOLLOW the TA unless he stops, because you can hardly catch them up.
My advice is to first observe how they do the assignment,
subsequently try on your own and ask ur TA after the demonstrations.
reviews.comment_grading:
Weighting
=====================
Knowledge Check Quizzes
0%  (likely to be changed)

In-class Quizzes
10%

Computer Lab
25%  (including attendance, assignments and the final-week project)

Mid-term Exam
25%

Final Exam
40%
=====================
Someone claimed the professor only gave 1 student an A+ (source: MSSSUG) (class size: 120 ppl)

Nevertheless, B range or above shall never be difficult,
if you have put some effort in it,
and you have understood most of the topics.

Remarks: The prof kept mentioning 'Next semester, I will ask students to do a presentation on that',
so if you can grasp such chances, getting an A+ might be less difficult!
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends on your attitude to be honest.
If you are serious, and interested, you won't be concerned by the workload.
The bottom line is that it's still manageable to most students.
Also
Better ask your friends if you don't understand.

reviews.author: Sid
reviews.comment_content: The content is related to basic automotive engineering in which you are given an introduction to different components of automobiles. If you are slightly interested in automobiles, you should definitely take this course as it does not require any pre requisites and it enhances your knowledge a lot. You also get to learn the most widely used design software, SolidWorks.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since the content is very basic, teaching does not matter much. However, the lectures sometimes become boring and monotonous.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not much as it is just a fundamental mech course. There is no homework. When I took the course, there wasn't even midterm. You have weekly labs in which you get to learn different aspects of SolidWorks designing which is absolutely necessary if your intended major is MECH.
